, across the Golden Gate bridge from
.  Sausalito is a unique and picturesque community, perched on a hillside between the San Francisco Bay and the
Sausalito proper has no airports, instead use one of the three bay area airports:
. From there you can get to Sausalito.

Sausalito is just over the Golden Gate Bridge (US 101) from San Francisco. Just take the first exit (Alexander Avenue) after crossing the bridge and follow it into town.  If coming from the north, exit at the sign marked from Sausalito, turn left, and make your way down Bridgeway into town.

value: content= Offers ferry service to/from Pier 41 in San Francisco's
content=Offers ferry service to/from the historic Ferry Building in San Francisco's

A very popular cycle for tourists to

is to hire a bike, cycle over the Golden Gate Bridge, and then down into Sausalito.  Planning this the previous day will make sure you arrive in Sausalito in time for brunch.  If worn out from the ride, you can catch the ferry back to San Francisco; the ferries have lots of capacity to carry bikes. A map of the route is available from most bike hire places in San Francisco.

Most of the frequently visited waterfront area can be seen on foot and are within easy walking distance from the ferry landing.  Make sure to head north on your walk along Bridgeway to Caledonia Street - it's full of great stores, restaurants, cafes and art studios.

Sausalito is also an easy town to bike in. A favorite local ride is to Sam's Restaurant in

for lunch or drinks on the huge (and very entertaining!) outdoor deck.  It always seems to be sunny there, so bring your hat and sunscreen.  Another not to be missed ride is from Sausalito to Mill Valley (hit the Depot for a great lunch) and on up any bike trail on Mt. Tamalpais.

value: content=Every 2nd Wednesday of the month you can tour art studios and galleries along Bridgeway.
alt=Nautical History Tours and Treasure Hunts

content=In depth insider's tour of the historic Sausalito waterfront inculdes Historic Houseboats, WWII shipyards, Art Studios, Wooden Boat Center. Refreshements served at the end of the tour in the boat lettering shop next to the WWII shipways. Every Weekend. Call To Reserve.

For a directory of local art galleries, see

content=Art studio of Victoria Colella.  Visit the last artist's studio of it's kind on the Sausalito waterfront and see Victoria's illustrious Folk Art Collection. By appointment only.

content=A very eclectic shop filled with a range of historical hard to find and interesting pieces. A great place to buy great gifts or get your mind going for finding great gifts. Really fun shopping.
content=Suite B. John has an ever changing selection of fine furniture and collectibles on display in his workshop, as well as incredible paintings and photography in his gallery area.
directions=in the Industrial Center Building at the north end of Sausalito

content=Visit and purchase art from one of the largest groups of talented, local artists in Northern California. Art studio tours April â€“ December plus an annual fun, free, family friendly event on Labor Day Weekend.
content=The largest location of local artists & galleries under one roof in Sausalito.
content=Suite A. A hip gallery that offers a collection of work from over 25 local artists, including great furniture.
directions=Arques Shipyard at end of Road 3 off Harbor Drive
content=Nautical sign specialist, with traditional signage on the waterfront. Carving, gilding, hand painted, custom vinyl designs available.

Sausalito is blessed with more fine restaurants than a town of 7,000 people should have. Whatever you're looking to eat, Sausalito probably has a restaurant serving it up. Beware the 'touristy' district, however. While there are a few genuinely good restaurants, there are also a fair number of establishments catering basic grub to tourists.

value: , Top-rated Indian-Mexican fusion cuisine.  Sounds weird, but has a fanatical following.
, has now closed and the building is for lease.
content=Excellent, very fresh, and well-prepared seafood. Fish is best enjoyed on a sunny day,
on the large deck overlooking a fishing harbor on the north side of town. Despite being off the beaten path, Fish is always crowded on nice days. Cash only.

content=Fred's is a Sausalito institution. Fred's has only 6 tables, each seating 4-6 people. You're most likely to be seated with others at 'your' table, which often leads to interesting conversations. One table at Fred's has a brass plaque reading "Stamtisch" which means

. Anyone can sit there if a chair is free. For breakfast, the Fred's French toast is pretty amazing. For those who prefer something a little more spicy, ask for the "Coyote Special", which is a cheese omelette covered with chili.
, Like Fred's, but less crazed and hectic.

content=Founded by one of the creators of Il Fornaio (back when Il Fornaio was small and intimate), it is an upscale version and really special. All dishes are prepared with care and sauces have the deep, rich flavorful tastes. Menu changes a lot daily.
content=A hole-in-the-wall, with the very little ambiance but delicious traditional Indian food served up by mom, Balbir, who goes from stove to counter in her apron.
content=One of the best sushi restaurants in the San Francisco Bay area, Sushi Ran serves up incredibly good and fresh sushi and modern Japanese cuisine. Received a Michelin star in October 2006.
content=Sidewalk Cafe, Art Shows, Live Jazz Music, Locals.
, Bridgeway. Sidewalk Fine Dining, fresh pasta on a menu that changes every day; does great Coffee.
, Princess Street. Coffee as you know it from any other city anywhere.

(formerly Caffe Trieste), 1000 Bridgeway. Always comes to mind for great San Francisco Bay Area Coffee, this is the Sausalito branch. Classic Bicycle rider destination. Internet WIFI, Live Jazz Music, Art Shows, Sidewalk Tables.

content=On a hillside overlooking Richardson Bay and listed on the National Register of Historic Places. The modern rooms are quiet, classy, comfortable and chic. The historic section of the hotel dates back to the late 1800s and has some "dream" rooms with fabulous views, and other hillside rooms, which may involve climbing many stairs. 3,000-square-foot spa and fitness center on premises.
content=Originally built in 1869, this is a historic bed and breakfast, boasting nine distinctively elegant rooms - many with king beds, fireplaces, spa tubs, and skyline bay views.
content=This is a boutique hotel on the water with unbelievable views.
name=Cavallo Point, The Lodge at the Golden Gate

content=Originally an Army base called Fort Baker, this late 1800's base was decommissioned, given to the National Park Service, and commissioned as a hotel. Amenities include fine dining and a spa. Great location for views, right below and to the east of the Golden Gate Bridge. Has some rooms where walking and stair-climbing are required. Room service, bar, restaurant, and a spa.

.  Ask for directions to the Spencer Avenue parking lot (on 101) and start your hike at the trailhead across from the lot.  It zig-zags up to a major trail where you take a right and then wind your way toward the ocean and beautiful ridge top views.  From here, you can hike the Marin Headlands pretty much to anywhere along the coast, depending on your time and ability.
